Emergency Response Program

Veolia's transfer operation at DRIR maintains an Emergency Action Plan that describes the actions to be taken by employees in the event of a spill, fire, explosion, or other emergencies. The Plan defines the
responsibilities of the employees designated as Emergency Coordinators at the facility. At all times,
there will be at least one Emergency Coordinator (EC) on call. In an emergency, the EC directs the operation's response personnel and controls all activities until local emergency responders arrive at the scene and the site is turned over to the responding authority.


The Emergency Action Plan outlines the procedures the EC follows in response to an emergency event
including the following:
    Activating the facility's internal communication system to alert all operations personnel and initiate
      facility evacuation procedures (if required);
    Assessing/identifying the character, exact source, amount, and extent of any contamination as well
      as possible hazards to human health or the environment.

Veolia's approach to release prevention and risk reduction is based on a specific hierarchy of controls, namely elimination, substitution, engineering, administrative controls, and finally PPE. Because it is Veolia's business to receive the chemicals as wastes for safe management, elimination and substitution are not applicable.

To minimize the risk of an accidental release using engineering controls, Veolia designed the process to utilize top loading with a stinger to fill the railcars, which reduces the risk posed by a release from the bottom valve of the railcar. Secondary containment is in place for the pumping operation. The buildup of static electricity is prevented by using conductive hoses and the electrical bonding of tank trucks, pumps, and railcars. To minimize vapor releases, vapors are balanced between the tanker and railcar. High-level alarms are present on the railcars (activate at 90% full), to prevent overfilling.

Administrative controls implemented to minimize the risk of an accidental release include:
    Standard Operating Procedures with job safety analysis for each part of the process. 
    Inspection programs covering equipment, materials, and processes to identify and correct deficiencies. 
    Hazardous Materials Management Plan that includes fire prevention and control requirements.
    Comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures. Refresher training is provided 
    at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

On the Corporate Level, the executive responsibility to safely manage all hazardous waste operations rests with the President and CEO of Environmental Services and Solutions. The Director of Health and Safety has the authority to develop and require the implementation of corporate-wide safety and health programs to promote a safe, healthful work environment and promote regulatory compliance. 

The Branch Health and Safety manager shall ensure that all elements of the CHSP are being implemented in compliance with all federal, state, and local regulations. The Branch General Manager is responsible for providing the necessary resources for meeting the requirements of the CHSP at the branch level and is responsible for the safety of their employees and the operations under their control. Operation Managers and Supervisors are responsible for the safety of their employees and operations under their control. They are to ensure that their employees are following the requirements set out in the program. Employees are responsible for working safely and following the requirements of the program. Employees are also responsible for reporting unsafe acts or conditions to their supervisors or managers.

Veolia is committed to protecting and enhancing the environment and to operating facilities in full
compliance with all applicable laws. Component number seven of Veolia's corporate Environmental Policy outlines Veolia's commitment to risk reduction:

Veolia will operate in a manner designed to minimize environmental, health, and safety hazards.

Veolia will minimize risk and protect employees and others in the vicinity of operations by employing
safe technologies and operating procedures and by being prepared for emergencies.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

Veolia Environmental Services (Veolia) operates a 10-day rail transfer operation (the facility) at the Denver Rock Island Railroad's Silver Yard in Denver, Colorado. The facility receives waste materials transported to the site via tank trucks of primarily organic solvent wastes from various manufacturers. Once on-site, the waste materials are consolidated into various railcars depending on how the material will be processed. Hazardous Wastes are shipped to Veolia or 3rd party facilities for treatment or disposal. Other materials suitable for use as feedstock are shipped to industrial customers as a product. 


There will be one process at the railyard that can store a regulated chemical (piperidine) in quantity sufficient to require the preparation and implementation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP). The process will be performed on an event basis for one year, and Veolia will terminate this RMP plan at the end of the year. 

The RMP regulated process involves the transloading of dimethylformamide (DMF) containing up to 7% piperidine from tank trucks delivered to the facility into railcars, with the heaviest car weighing 206,500 lbs. Once complete, Veolia will ship railcars off-site.   


At most, 16,000 pounds per railcar and 52,080 pound total piperidine may be present on-site in the DMF transloading process. There are no other processes at the facility currently storing, handling, using, or processing chemicals in quantities sufficient to require their inclusion in this RMP.
